conclusion: Understanding forces on the coil in the magnetic field and their effect on the balance.
Initial balance condition involves equality of torques on the balance arms.
Torque due to magnetic force is \( \tau_{\text{magnetic}} = n B I L^2 \sin(\theta) \) with \( \sin(\theta) = 1 \).
Torque due to gravitational force is \( \tau_{\text{gravitational}} = m_1 g L_1 = m_2 g L_2 \).
Initial balance condition: \( n B I L^2 = m_1 g L_1 = m_2 g L_2 \).
After reversing the current, the direction of magnetic force is reversed.
New magnetic torque is \( \tau_{\text{magnetic}}' = -n B I L^2 \).
New gravitational torque with added weight \( m \) is \( \tau_{\text{gravitational}}' = (m_1 + m) g L_1 = m_2 g L_2 \).
New balance condition: \( -n B I L^2 = (m_1 + m) g L_1 = m_2 g L_2 \).
From initial balance: \( n B I L^2 = m_1 g L_1 \).
From new balance: \( -n B I L^2 = (m_1 + m) g L_1 \).
Equating magnitudes: \( n B I L^2 = (m_1 + m) g L_1 \).
Substitute \( m_1 g L_1 = n B I L^2 \) into equation: \( m_1 g L_1 = (m_1 + m) g L_1 \).
Simplifying gives \( m_1 = m_1 + m \), leading to contradiction unless \( m = 0 \).
Use ratio of torques: \( \frac{n B I L^2}{m_1 g L_1} = \frac{(m_1 + m) g L_1}{-n B I L^2} \).
Equation becomes \( -n^2 B^2 I^2 L^4 = (m_1 + m) m_1 g^2 L_1^2 \).
